data.text: Instrumental records show that the global mean surface temperature has risen by approximately 1.2 °C since pre‑industrial times, while atmospheric CO₂ concentrations have increased from ~280 ppm to over 420 ppm—a correlation quantified by a climate sensitivity of roughly 3 °C per doubling of CO₂. This warming has already amplified the frequency of extreme heatwaves, which, according to the IPCC, are projected to increase the probability of days exceeding 40 °C by a factor of 5–10 in many mid‑latitude regions by 2050. Econometric analyses estimate that each additional degree Celsius of warming could reduce global GDP by 1–2 % per year, underscoring the escalating economic risk if emissions are not curbed.

Econometric analyses estimate that each additional degree Celsius of warming could reduce global GDP by 1–2\u202f% per year, underscoring the escalating economic risk if emissions are not curbed.'}

data.text: The doctrine of intergenerational justice, rooted in Rawlsian fairness, obligates the present generation to safeguard the climate so that future persons inherit a livable world rather than a compromised inheritance. From a Stoic standpoint, humanity’s rational nature calls us to live in harmony with the natural order, and willful disruption of atmospheric balance betrays that very rationality. Moreover, the historical evolution of the social contract—from Hobbes’ sovereign to a global commons—demands collective responsibility to prevent the “tragedy of the commons” that global warming epitomizes.

data.text: Instrumental records show that global mean surface temperature has risen about 1.2 °C since pre‑industrial times, with a linear trend of roughly 0.18 °C per decade over the past four decades (IPCC AR6). At the same time, ocean heat content has increased by ~0.5 × 10²³ J yr⁻¹, indicating that the majority of excess energy is being stored in the oceans and driving sea‑level rise and marine heatwaves. Climate models constrained by this energy imbalance estimate an equilibrium climate sensitivity of 2.5–4.0 °C, meaning that if current emissions continue, there is an >80 % probability of exceeding the 2 °C warming threshold by the 2050s. The associated economic damages are projected to be 2–4 % of global GDP per degree Celsius of warming, highlighting the rapidly escalating risk.

data.text: The accelerating climate crisis constitutes a profound violation of intergenerational justice, obligating the present generation to safeguard the ecological inheritance of future persons as a matter of moral duty. From a Kantian perspective, we must act according to a universal maxim that respects the rational agency of all humanity, which demands the reduction of greenhouse emissions rather than exploiting the planet for short‑term gain. Historically, the Industrial Revolution inaugurated an unprecedented anthropogenic impact on the atmosphere, and recognizing this legacy compels us to rectify the imbalance through ethically grounded policy and collective responsibility.

data.text: Instrumental records show a mean global surface temperature increase of 1.2 °C since pre‑industrial times, corresponding to a net anthropogenic radiative forcing of roughly +2.3 W m⁻² (IPCC AR6). Climate‑model ensembles attribute over 90 % of this forcing to CO₂ and other greenhouse gases, yielding an equilibrium climate sensitivity of 2.5–4 °C per doubling of CO₂, which implies an additional 0.5–0.8 °C rise by 2050 under current emission trajectories. Integrated assessment models estimate that exceeding a 2 °C warming threshold would increase the expected global economic loss from climate‑related damages from ~1 % to >5 % of GDP per annum, a risk magnitude that justifies immediate mitigation.

Integrated assessment models estimate that exceeding a 2\u202f°C warming threshold would increase the expected global economic loss from climate‑related damages from ~1\u202f% to >5\u202f% of GDP per annum, a risk magnitude that justifies immediate mitigation.', 'agent_view': []}

data.text: From a Kantian perspective, the duty to preserve the planet for future rational agents imposes a categorical imperative to curb emissions, regardless of short‑term convenience. Historically, the Anthropocene marks a rupture in humanity’s stewardship, echoing the Stoic warning that we must align our actions with the natural order rather than dominate it. Moreover, a utilitarian calculus demands that the disproportionate suffering of vulnerable populations—who contribute least to greenhouse gases—be mitigated as a matter of distributive justice.

data.text: Recent satellite observations show that the Earth’s average surface temperature has risen by 1.2 °C since pre‑industrial levels, correlating with a 48 % increase in atmospheric CO₂ concentrations from 280 ppm to 420 ppm (IPCC AR6, 2021). Climate models calibrated to these forcings project a 0.3–0.5 °C per decade warming rate, which would push global mean temperatures beyond the 1.5 °C threshold by the early 2030s under current emission trajectories. Exceeding this limit raises the probability of exceeding a 5 % chance of catastrophic sea‑level rise (>1 m by 2100), as quantified by probabilistic risk assessments. Consequently, immediate mitigation—reducing CO₂ emissions by at least 45 % by 2030—offers the most cost‑effective strategy to limit these high‑impact outcomes.

data.text: The ethical imperative to mitigate global warming can be grounded in the principle of intergenerational justice, which obliges the present generation to preserve the planet’s ecological integrity for future peoples who have no voice in current policy decisions. Historically, the Enlightenment’s emphasis on rational stewardship of nature was eclipsed by industrial capitalism’s exploitation of externalities; restoring that rationalist ethic demands that we recognize climate stewardship as a collective moral duty rather than a market commodity. Moreover, the cosmopolitan notion of a shared humanity compels us to view the climate crisis not as a series of national problems but as a universal moral challenge that tests our capacity for global solidarity.
